hints.content: Start by understanding the operations you need to handle. You have four types: integers, '+', 'D', and 'C'. Make sure you know what each operation does to the score record.
Consider how you will store the scores. A list or array can be a good choice, as you can easily append new scores and remove the last score when needed.
When you encounter an integer, remember to convert it from a string to an integer before adding it to your score record.
For the '+' operation, you need to sum the last two scores in your record. Make sure to check that there are at least two scores before performing this operation.
The 'D' operation requires you to double the last score. Ensure you handle cases where the record might be empty or only has one score when this operation is called.
The 'C' operation should remove the last score from your record. Think about how you will implement this using list operations.
After processing all operations, you'll need to calculate the total sum of the scores in your record. This can be done using a simple sum function on your list.
Pay attention to edge cases, such as when the record becomes empty after a 'C' operation. Ensure your code handles this gracefully.
Remember that the constraints guarantee valid operations. You won't encounter an invalid operation, so you can focus on implementing the logic without additional checks for validity.
As a final step, make sure to return the total sum of the scores after processing all operations. This is the expected output of your function.

questionNotes: You must handle up to 1000 operations.
The input integers range from -30,000 to 30,000.
For '+' operation, there will always be at least two previous scores.
For 'C' and 'D' operations, there will always be at least one previous score.
